title: Stockmarket returns in a world of negative rates
text:
Correspondingly, a broad index in Aussie bonds across all maturities has earned you 9 per cent this year (remembering that bond prices rise as yields fall).

These powerful gains from staid government securities have come because central banks are slashing rates to stop a downturn turning into something worse.

The Aussie economy's growth slowed to 1.4 per cent over the year to June, or more than half the pace at which it was expanding in mid-2018. Global trade and manufacturing has collapsed. China's economy is weakening. Germany is on the brink of recession.

The persistent threat from the US-China trade war, among other geopolitical worries, has added urgency to the RBA's easing policy and governor Philip Lowe has indicated global risks could trigger another cut to 0.75 per cent on Tuesday.

No wonder, then, that bond yields have dropped. Bond yields reflect the outlook for growth and inflation, and what this will mean for the path of official cash rates. Yields fall as pessimism rises.

Yet at the same time as growing pessimism has helped bond returns, Aussie shares have surged by more than 18 per cent in 2019. Add in dividends and you get more like 24 per cent. The performance figures for the American bond and stock holdings are almost identical.

This is not "normal". Historically, stock prices have suffered during such periods as investors begin to factor in lower expected profits.

If we look at the industrials component of the ASX – essentially those businesses outside the financials, listed property and resources sectors – we can see that the earnings outlook for these businesses has indeed deteriorated in 2019.

But this has been more than offset by two things: investors' willingness to pay more for companies as lower rates boost the calculated value of future (even lower) earnings; and falling rates and a dearth of income-producing assets driving people towards stocks offering solid dividends.

But why has this relationship between stocks and yields changed, and when did it happen? And what does it mean for investors?

Macquarie analysts have been examining these questions. They conclude that "something changed in financial markets around 2012 that led markets to respond differently to lower bond yields".

Their "working hypothesis is that the key development in 2012 was the shift to NIRP, or negative interest rate policy, which began in Denmark in July 2012".

They examined how the ASX's industrial's index has behaved through the cycle in the decade before the advent of negative rates versus the years since.

They split the cycle into downturn (yields are lower than a year prior and falling – probably where we are today); recovery (yields are still lower than a year ago but past their lows); expansion (bond rates are higher than a year earlier and are rising); and then slowdown (yields still higher than they were but past their peak).

The analysis shows how, in the pre-negative rates era, investors typically lost money in industrial stocks during a slowdown (such as this year), but then enjoyed a strong rally in the recovery.

Advertisement

Since 2012 there have only been two months where a central bank hasn't had a policy rate below zero, and this relationship between yields and stocks has changed.

By enacting extreme policies, central bankers have effectively pulled forward gains in the recovery period to prop up returns in the downturn. This allows a little money to be made in the downturn as well as in the recovery – albeit less before 2012.

Essentially, central banks have engineered a world in which industrial stocks provide returns no matter what point we are in the bond cycle. This is highly lucrative, with average returns for industrial stocks of 9 per cent in a world of extraordinarily easy policy, against 2 per cent over the decade preceding it.

So what are the implications?

For one, valuations for listed industrial businesses have stayed elevated, so expect underwhelming returns in any recovery. Assuming we stay in a low-growth world and any earnings rebound will be modest, then "the key risk" for shareholders would be a rapid rise in bond yields during the "recovery" phase.

"What was once a good time to own stocks could instead favour cash, as bond and stock prices fall," they write.

The Macquarie analysts believe a recession could be the circuit breaker for this new relationship between yields and stockmarket returns.

For example, bond rates and share prices fell in the final months of 2018 amid growing fears of a US recession and as Aussie house prices were tanking at an accelerating rate.

"That said, the trends we highlight could become more pronounced if [negative rates] were to come to Australia."
description: By pushing official rates below zero, central banks have altered the way key financial assets perform through the cycle. What's less clear is what happens next.
